comments.commentBody:
America lacks a tradition exercised in some countries: if you are an official and fundamentally disagree with a policy you are expected to advocate or enforce, you resign, thus calling principled attention to your position.

Every now and then people wonder if it will happen here (e.g. Colin Powell), but it never does. The S.E.C. story documented here might, in another society, have produced such resignations at the time. Instead of demonstrating the seriousness of one's belief by laying something personal on the line, the tendency in the U.S. is either to shut up or hinder any governmental action at no cost to oneself (e.g. threatened filibusters.)
Robert in NH:  compassion for crackheads but not for whistleblowers?  Got it.

Uncle Ebeneezer: "The beatings will continue until moral improves."

Another take might be: morale didn't improve. Its just after so much pain and so much screeming, the victims lose their voice box and have become numb to the pain.

Calling Doctor Howard, Doctor Fine, Doctor Howard.

I think my favorite Stooges is when they became plumbers and nearly destroy a mansion. That one started out with them trying to get lunch by fishing in a pet store aquairium.

Long ago I predicted that the austerians would declare victory 18 months before the next election, in Spring 2015, and decide that once again its time to invest in England. It takes about 18 months for economic policies to be fully felt. So, now is the perfect time for Cameron's government to declare victory and begin spending again, and then hope the voters have short memories.

Beyond the power play of it, Mr. Khodorkovsky is not innocent to the plight brought upon the Russian people during the period previous to the rise to power of Mr. Putin. He conspired with foreign interests to destroy the Russian economy (or whatever was left after the fall of the Soviet Union). Now of course those powerful interests have provided the world with a cynical narrative about the Mr. Khodorkovsky case making him look like a victim of political prosecution.

You are right. Might makes right is supplanting the economic rule of law.

Yes, public complicity is a crucial element in our phony democracy. The working class gop voters have collaborated in their own destruction. They're egged on by their contempt for the class below, especially if a darker skin shade. Class and race resentment has been engineered to win elections, while the engineers deny we even have classes in our renowned 'meritocracy.'

The S. Court saying money equals free speech put a veneer of legality on our election deceptions. Who could resist it?

But there was a time when CEOs and MBAs still had some sense of responsibility to the rest of society. Glass Steagall was accepted for generations. They paid higher taxes and they dealt with the equalizing factor of unions.

Corporations, believe it or not, once took pride in giving employers raises and enhanced benefits. It's like another planet. This contrast is what the media must now portray, showing different generations of families and how their security is in a downward spiral, compared to the past.
You are right on this one, Verona (New Jersey) Socrates. Most of the Russian czars were not very good, though, even the Terribles and the Greats.
Putin is cooking with gas.
Let's hope.

Love to see Putin release Mr. Khodorkovsky , because it will be  Putin downfall.. Mr. Khodorkovsky  has got billions hidden away and will eventually mount a challenge to Putin's power. It will be a win, win for Russia.
Woe to political opponents jailed after Sochi - it could be really long wait until another Olympics in Russia.
Hmmm? I smell the Olympics!

Sarah: There will be no protests seen by the outside world at Sochi. The cameras will be under Kremlin control. Anything that erupts will be dealt with immediately, and off camera.

About the only thing that can go wrong is a lack of snow. Fingers crossed!

How long has this guy been in office?

Here in America, after FDR broke tradition of two years, Congress made that tradition official. My point? Putin worries me that he is so ingrained with power in Russia, and after so long, why has he yet to step down despite his claims that he supports a free, democratic society?

If not him, I'm concerned that the next guy may follow his example and might just remain there... permanently.

You state, "Ivan IV, aka Ivan the Terrible, was terrible to the magnates and oligarchs." I would hope so. After all, he was Ivan the Terrible.

But forgive me for not agreeing with your equivalence argument after having read your little history lesson.

With all their flaws, Great Britain and the United States have improved the quality of life for the vast majority of their inhabitants over the years. There are warts and there is still work to do. But, these two great nations are not equivalent to Russia.

Russia/the USSR/the Russian Empire has just been one successful rebranding effort. The Lorenz curve for that country, no matter what you call it, has remained unchanged over centuries. About 1% of the population has owned 99% of the wealth.
how is US any different, where Bush pardoned Scooter Libby?

Following the NSA scandal, many on these pages wondered if the we're becoming a totalitarian state. I think this article provides some contrast between the U.S. and a place where people are jailed and released on a czar 's whim.

Russia threat comes not from itself, but from its created enemies and lack of self control. Sheesh, how many weapons are now unaccounted for after the Soviet Union's demise?

Yes, Russia's industry is crumbling but that doesn't mean we should let our guard down. I'd hate to imagine a scenario where Russia becomes desperate enough to join a growing anti-west side just to survive.

I always though the best of the Russian genus, but the great puzzlement is how they always gravitate toward a despot. Could it be because of a cynicism developed over centuries of despots, they developed a way to "wiggle" around them, be it their wonderfully ironic humor or their underground systems of survival? I may be naïve, but I bet there is not a Russian who deep down understands that Putin is nothing more than a bully, ruling though, IMO, an arrested sense of machismo infused with a Napoleonic complex - not to mention a huge arsenal of weapons at his disposal.

I can tell you that Russians on this situation think. The matter is that both Putin and Khodorkovsky participated in one criminal case and laundered the money received from oil extraction. But Khodorkovsky simply didn't share part of the income with Putin, besides wanted to go to the power. Therefore Putin arrested him. But both of them are criminals, thieves.

Smart guy, easing up before the olympic games, freeing a guy who insulted him now that he's no longer dangerous, freeing Nadezhda Tolokonokova and her bandmates.  I guy I know who lived there said, everything in Russia is done on the basis of, do this or I will punish you.  He's really about the best we can hope for.

Imagine the power that Putin has, in this day and age, and in such an major country, in what we call the international community.

He can (legally) put away a political enemy with such ease. He can also release him with equal ease. A dream for any wannabe despot.

I am eternally thankful to be US Citizen.

Egan's analogy with the Irish famine should remind us that Social Darwinism predates Darwin.  We seem to have a gene for self-righteousness, and surely for selfishness.  Read Thomas Sowell, who argues that it's not "greedy" to keep one's own money while refusing to address the needs of those without.  Sadly, conservatives have turned greed into a virtue.  They have effectively managed to turn charity and a social conscience into two of the seven deadly sins.

The paradox, it seems to be, lies in the fact that most of those who appear to support social Darwinism are those who deny the fact of evolution, while all the professional biologists I know (that's a lot - I'm one myself) utterly reject social Darwinism.

p.

This has been going on a long time:

"It is a principle of human nature to hate those whom we have injured."

From Agricola of Tacitus c. 98

Even though I study American history I am frequently caught off guard when old ideas once again circulate. Social Darwinism is a bankrupt, vile ideology with a mean-spirited view of humankind. How could modern Americans possible embrace this nonsense? But here it is. Once again when capitalism fails us miserably by concentrating wealth in the hands of a few, precisely what it is structured to do, there are some Americans who want to blame poverty not on capitalism but on people who just don't work hard enough, or are simply unprepared and unlucky, or who are enticed by a government program that provides $300 a week subsistence, or whatever. If your are not in the top 20% of income it is your own darn fault.

Yes, such ideology exists to permit us to believe our wealth is all our own doing and to help us feel better about doing nothing for those in great need.

Thank you, Mr. Egan, for reminding us all of the meanness of such thinking and for naming the political leaders who hold such low opinion of humankind.

Putin did not get rid of the oligarchs, for that would meant to start another cycle of robbery and murder amongst elites in Russia, he merely showed them that they should stay out of politics and pay taxes.

People are acting like Putin got rid of the oligarchs when in reality he only got rid of the ones who opposed him. There are still oligarchs in Russia today--they're all just friends and allies of Putin.

"Trade today will be interesting from an Asian-centric point of view, as the Chinese repo rates continue to react to policy changes around banking. The changes by the PBoC and the central government are very positive steps towards a more liberal and freely floating interbank lending rate, and provide insight into the steps that may be taken to see a freely floating CNY in years to come http://www.stockmaster.in/hang_seng.html

GDP and austerity ought to be Gini indexed. Gini is the coefficient that measures the inequality of wealth distribution. GDP can augment, while average, or median, family income goes down. Exactly as it has been doing in the USA since the beginning of this Greater Depression.

Clearly, austerity can affect the 99% and not the top .1%. So both GDP and austerity can be weapons that a new aristocracy is using to create a new serfdom.

Most of Mr. Osborne colleagues in this Cameron government are immensely rich. Only the USA, the USSR (aka Russia) and other banana republics have governments of extremely rich individuals, and such government are not after economic performance or the common welfare. They are after imposing ever more plutocracy...
http://patriceayme.wordpress.com/2013/12/19/universe-100-billion-years-old/
Thanks, 5.  It looks like the colorized version.  Have you ever seen Casablanca in the colorized version?  Not the same.
Morra, even the squirrels get it.  Save nuts in the summer (when you can), and eat them in the winter (when you can't).  Good Comment though.

Isn`t it amazing how we repeat the same mistakes, even as we have more and more data.

The Egyptians understood macroeconomics better than the austerians: they saved and stored wheat in the 7 years of the fat cattle and then they distributed that saved wheat in the 7 years of lean cattle. And that was 3,500 years ago!

I almost threw the hot coffee at the ex-CEO of a major bank, who this morning on CNBC, was blaming the lack of recovery on high taxes and the fact that large corporation have a trillion $ offshore as it would cost too much to repatriate. Yes, repatriation might be good if the money would be invested locally, but what would cause that money to be invested when there is already over 5 trillion $ languising on corporate balance sheets which has not been invested. Had the government had that money it would invest it in rebuilding infrastucture, education, research, etc., etc., etc., all job creating projects which would spur demand and growth.

I read this story because I instantly recognized it as from Dante's Inferno. This was the title of my thesis exhibition in graduate school that coincided with my parent's rapid descent into dementia and the loss of all their worldly possessions. I gravitated to the Inferno as my family and life disintegrated and I was overcome with helplessness in my inability to help anyone.

The essay focuses on why this work and this first line in particular resonated with me so much. It was about my parents loosing themselves, me loosing my own way and becoming lost in a grief I could neither articulate or describe in words. The part of the passage that was the most interesting to me was the section where he looses his way in the wood. In the dark wood, I lost my way. The nature of the passage is unclear about how he looses his way, which seemed to me how we ourselves loose our way. We turn around and all of a sudden we are lost.

The inferno allows us to wrestle with the nature of mortality. I have made a life for myself and have my own family, but my experience informs how I see the world. After all, Dante does return to the earthly wold.
